commit 2df8b776cf21861211e206d3f372258bb121c8e2
Author: Pedro Pi√±era <pedro@pepicrft.me>
Date:   Tue Feb 10 18:26:57 2026 +0100

    feat(skills): publish skills to tuist/agent-skills repo instead of NPM
    
    Instead of publishing the @tuist/skills NPM package (which was failing due to OIDC issues), the release workflow now pushes skill files directly to the tuist/agent-skills GitHub repository and creates version tags there.
    
    Entire-Checkpoint: b226fcfcdb5d

 skills/package.json           | 21 ---------------------
 2 files changed, 20 insertions(+), 43 deletions(-)

commit 2df8b776cf21861211e206d3f372258bb121c8e2
Author: Pedro Pi√±era <pedro@pepicrft.me>
Date:   Tue Feb 10 18:26:57 2026 +0100

    feat(skills): publish skills to tuist/agent-skills repo instead of NPM
    
    Instead of publishing the @tuist/skills NPM package (which was failing due to OIDC issues), the release workflow now pushes skill files directly to the tuist/agent-skills GitHub repository and creates version tags there.
    
    Entire-Checkpoint: b226fcfcdb5d

diff --git a/.github/workflows/release.yml b/.github/workflows/release.yml
index 509f9f22bb..6327de7523 100644
--- a/.github/workflows/release.yml
+++ b/.github/workflows/release.yml
@@ -929,13 +929,9 @@ jobs:
     if: needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-should-release == 'true'
     runs-on: ubuntu-latest
     timeout-minutes: 15
-    permissions:
-      id-token: write
-      contents: read
     env:
-      GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
+      GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.TUIST_GITHUB_TOKEN }}
     outputs:
-      artifacts-uploaded: ${{ steps.upload.outputs.uploaded }}
       release-notes: ${{ steps.release-notes.outputs.RELEASE_NOTES }}
     steps:
       - uses: actions/checkout@v4
@@ -943,12 +939,6 @@ jobs:
           fetch-depth: 0
       - uses: jdx/mise-action@v2
 
-      - name: Setup Node.js
-        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
-        with:
-          node-version: 24
-          registry-url: https://registry.npmjs.org
-
       - name: Get release notes
         id: release-notes
         run: |
@@ -963,10 +953,6 @@ jobs:
           fi
           echo "EOF" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
 
-      - name: Update version
-        working-directory: skills
-        run: npm version ${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-next-version-number }} --no-git-tag-version
-
       - name: Update CHANGELOG.md
         working-directory: skills
         run: |
@@ -979,18 +965,30 @@ jobs:
             git cliff --include-path "skills/**/*" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" --bump -o CHANGELOG.md 2>/dev/null
           fi
 
-      - name: Publish to NPM
-        working-directory: skills
-        run: npm publish --provenance --access public
+      - name: Push to tuist/agent-skills
+        run: |
+          VERSION="${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-next-version-number }}"
+          git clone https://x-access-token:${GITHUB_TOKEN}@github.com/tuist/agent-skills.git /tmp/agent-skills
+          rm -rf /tmp/agent-skills/skills
+          cp -r skills/skills /tmp/agent-skills/skills
+          cd /tmp/agent-skills
+          git config user.name "github-actions"
+          git config user.email "github-actions@github.com"
+          git add -A
+          if ! git diff --cached --quiet; then
+            git commit -m "Release ${VERSION}"
+            git tag "${VERSION}"
+            git push origin main --tags
+          else
+            echo "No changes to push"
+          fi
 
       - name: Upload Skills artifacts
-        id: upload
         uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
         with:
           name: skills-artifacts
           path: |
             skills/CHANGELOG.md
-            skills/package.json
           retention-days: 1
 
   commit-and-release:
@@ -1191,7 +1189,7 @@ jobs:
           name: Skills ${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-next-version-number }}
           tag_name: ${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-next-version }}
           body: |
-            NPM package: `@tuist/skills@${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-next-version-number }}`
+            GitHub: https://github.com/tuist/agent-skills/releases/tag/${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-next-version-number }}
 
             ${{ needs.release-skills.outputs.release-notes }}
 
@@ -1243,7 +1241,7 @@ jobs:
           fi
 
           if [ "${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.skills-should-release }}" == "true" ] && [ "${{ needs.release-skills.result }}" == "success" ]; then
-            git add skills/CHANGELOG.md skills/package.json
+            git add skills/CHANGELOG.md
             FILES_ADDED=true
           fi

1‚Üí# git-cliff ~ configuration file
     2‚Üí# https://git-cliff.org/docs/configuration
     3‚Üí
     4‚Üí[bump]
     5‚Üíinitial_tag = "0.1.0"
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí[remote.github]
     8‚Üíowner = "tuist"
     9‚Üírepo = "tuist"
    10‚Üí
    11‚Üí[changelog]
    12‚Üí# template for the changelog header
    13‚Üíheader = """
    14‚Üí# Changelog
    15‚Üí
    16‚ÜíAll notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.
    17‚Üí"""
    18‚Üí# template for the changelog body
    19‚Üí# https://keats.github.io/tera/docs/#introduction
    20‚Üíbody = """
    21‚Üí## What's Changed
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí{%- if version %} in {{ version }}{%- endif -%}
    24‚Üí<!-- RELEASE NOTES START -->
    25‚Üí{% for group, commits in commits | group_by(attribute="group") %}
    26‚Üí### {{ group | striptags | trim }}
    27‚Üí{% for commit in commits %}
    28‚Üí  {% if commit.github.pr_title -%}
    29‚Üí    {%- set commit_message = commit.github.pr_title -%}
    30‚Üí  {%- else -%}
    31‚Üí    {%- set commit_message = commit.message -%}
    32‚Üí  {%- endif -%}
    33‚Üí  * {{ commit_message | split(pat="\n") | first | trim }}\
    34‚Üí    {% if commit.github.username %} by [@{{ commit.github.username }}](https://github.com/{{ commit.github.username }}){%- endif -%}
    35‚Üí    {% if commit.github.pr_number %} in \
    36‚Üí      [#{{ commit.github.pr_number }}]({{ self::remote_url() }}/pull/{{ commit.github.pr_number }}) \
    37‚Üí    {%- endif %}
    38‚Üí{%- endfor -%}
    39‚Üí{% endfor %}
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí{%- if github -%}
    42‚Üí{% if github.contributors | filter(attribute="is_first_time", value=true) | length != 0 %}
    43‚Üí  {% raw %}\n{% endraw -%}
    44‚Üí  ## New Contributors
    45‚Üí{%- endif %}\
    46‚Üí{% for contributor in github.contributors | filter(attribute="is_first_time", value=true) %}
    47‚Üí  * [@{{ contributor.username }}](https://github.com/{{ contributor.username }}) made their first contribution
    48‚Üí    {%- if contributor.pr_number %} in \
    49‚Üí      [#{{ contributor.pr_number }}]({{ self::remote_url() }}/pull/{{ contributor.pr_number }}) \
    50‚Üí    {%- endif %}
    51‚Üí{%- endfor -%}
    52‚Üí{%- endif -%}
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí{% if version %}
    55‚Üí    {% if previous.version %}
    56‚Üí      **Full Changelog**: {{ self::remote_url() }}/compare/{{ previous.version }}...{{ version }}
    57‚Üí    {% endif %}
    58‚Üí{% else -%}
    59‚Üí  {% raw %}\n{% endraw %}
    60‚Üí{% endif %}
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí{%- macro remote_url() -%}
    63‚Üí  https://github.com/{{ remote.github.owner }}/{{ remote.github.repo }}
    64‚Üí{%- endmacro -%}
    65‚Üí"""
    66‚Üí# remove the leading and trailing whitespace from the template
    67‚Üítrim = true
    68‚Üí# changelog footer
    69‚Üífooter = """
    70‚Üí<!-- generated by git-cliff -->
    71‚Üí"""
    72‚Üí# postprocessors
    73‚Üípostprocessors = [
    74‚Üí    # Remove commit type prefix from changelog entries
    75‚Üí    { pattern = '\* (feat|fix|docs?|perf|refactor|style|test|chore|ci)(\([^)]*\))?:\s*', replace = "* " },
    76‚Üí]
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí[git]
    79‚Üí# parse the commits based on https://www.conventionalcommits.org
    80‚Üíconventional_commits = true
    81‚Üí# filter out the commits that are not conventional
    82‚Üífilter_unconventional = true
    83‚Üí# process each line of a commit as an individual commit
    84‚Üísplit_commits = false
    85‚Üí# regex for preprocessing the commit messages
    86‚Üícommit_preprocessors = [
    87‚Üí    # remove issue numbers from commits
    88‚Üí    { pattern = '\((\w+\s)?#([0-9]+)\)', replace = "" },
    89‚Üí]
    90‚Üí# regex for parsing and grouping commits
    91‚Üícommit_parsers = [
    92‚Üí    # Include commits with (skills) scope (supports multi-scope like "feat(cli,skills)")
    93‚Üí    { message = "^feat\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 0 -->‚õ∞Ô∏è  Features" },
    94‚Üí    { message = "^fix\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 1 -->üêõ Bug Fixes" },
    95‚Üí    { message = "^docs?\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 3 -->üìö Documentation" },
    96‚Üí    { message = "^perf\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 4 -->‚ö° Performance" },
    97‚Üí    { message = "^refactor\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 2 -->üöú Refactor" },
    98‚Üí    { message = "^style\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 5 -->üé® Styling" },
    99‚Üí    { message = "^test\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", group = "<!-- 6 -->üß™ Testing" },
   100‚Üí    { message = "^chore\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", skip = true },
   101‚Üí    { message = "^ci\\([^)]*\\bskills\\b[^)]*\\)", skip = true },
   102‚Üí    # Skip any other scoped commits
   103‚Üí    { message = "^[a-z]+\\([^)]+\\)", skip = true },
   104‚Üí]
   105‚Üí# protect breaking changes from being skipped due to matching a skipping commit_parser
   106‚Üíprotect_breaking_commits = false
   107‚Üí# filter out the commits that are not matched by commit parsers
   108‚Üífilter_commits = true
   109‚Üí# regex for matching git tags
   110‚Üítag_pattern = "skills@[0-9].*"
   111‚Üí# regex for skipping tags
   112‚Üískip_tags = "beta|alpha"
   113‚Üí# regex for ignoring tags
   114‚Üíignore_tags = "rc"
   115‚Üí# sort the tags topologically
   116‚Üítopo_order = false
   117‚Üí# sort the commits inside sections by oldest/newest order
   118‚Üísort_commits = "newest"
   119‚Üí

1‚Üí---
     2‚Üíname: using-tuist-generated-projects
     3‚Üídescription: Guides day-to-day work in Tuist-generated Xcode workspaces: generation, build and test commands, and buildable folders. Use when working in a Tuist-generated project or when users mention `tuist generate`, `xcodebuild test`, or generated workspaces.
     4‚Üí---
     5‚Üí
     6‚Üí# Using Tuist Generated Projects
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí## Quick Start
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí```bash
    11‚Üí# Generate workspace without opening Xcode
    12‚Üítuist generate --no-open
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí# Build a scheme with xcodebuild
    15‚Üíxcodebuild build -workspace App.xcworkspace -scheme App
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí# Run tests with xcodebuild
    18‚Üíxcodebuild test -workspace App.xcworkspace -scheme AppTests -only-testing AppTests/MyTestCase
    19‚Üí```
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí## Project definition
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí### Prefer buildable folders
    24‚Üí
    25‚ÜíUse `buildableFolders` instead of `sources` and `resources` globs. Buildable folders stay synchronized with the file system, so adding or removing files does not require regeneration.
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí```swift
    28‚Üílet target = Target(
    29‚Üí  name: "App",
    30‚Üí  buildableFolders: [
    31‚Üí    "App/Sources",
    32‚Üí    "App/Resources",
    33‚Üí  ]
    34‚Üí)
    35‚Üí```
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí### Tag targets for focus
    38‚Üí
    39‚ÜíUse target tags to group areas of the project, for example:
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí- `tag:team:*`
    42‚Üí- `tag:feature:*`
    43‚Üí- `tag:layer:*`
    44‚Üí
    45‚ÜíThese tags make it easier to scope generation and testing later.
    46‚Üí
    47‚ÜíExample target metadata with tags:
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí```swift
    50‚Üílet target = Target(
    51‚Üí  name: "PaymentsUI",
    52‚Üí  metadata: .metadata(tags: [
    53‚Üí    "tag:team:commerce",
    54‚Üí    "tag:feature:payments",
    55‚Üí    "tag:layer:ui",
    56‚Üí  ])
    57‚Üí)
    58‚Üí```
    59‚Üí
    60‚ÜíWhen working on a focused area, generate only what you need:
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí```bash
    63‚Üítuist generate tag:feature:payments
    64‚Üítuist generate PaymentsUI PaymentsTests
    65‚Üí```
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí### Align build configurations
    68‚Üí
    69‚ÜíKeep build configurations aligned between the project and external dependencies. Use `PackageSettings(settings: .settings(configurations: []))` to mirror project configurations; mismatches emit warnings.
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí## Workflows
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí### Generate intentionally
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí- Use `tuist generate --no-open` in automation and scripts to avoid launching Xcode.
    76‚Üí- Regenerate when any manifest changes (or the dependency graph changes).
    77‚Üí- If generation fails due to missing products, run `tuist install` to resolve dependencies and retry.
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí### Build with xcodebuild
    80‚Üí
    81‚ÜíUse `xcodebuild build` against the generated workspace and scheme.
    82‚Üí
    83‚Üí```bash
    84‚Üíxcodebuild build \
    85‚Üí  -workspace App.xcworkspace \
    86‚Üí  -scheme App \
    87‚Üí  -destination "generic/platform=iOS Simulator"
    88‚Üí```
    89‚Üí
    90‚Üí### Test with xcodebuild
    91‚Üí
    92‚ÜíUse `xcodebuild test` for running tests locally. Prefer it over `tuist test` because `tuist test` regenerates the project on each invocation, which slows down iteration.
    93‚Üí
    94‚ÜíTo optimize test run time:
    95‚Üí
    96‚Üí- **Use `--only-testing`** to run only the specific test suite or test case you are working on, instead of the full target.
    97‚Üí- **Pick the scheme with the fewest compilation targets** that still includes the test target you need. This minimizes build time before tests run.
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí```bash
   100‚Üí# Run a specific test suite
   101‚Üíxcodebuild test \
   102‚Üí  -workspace App.xcworkspace \
   103‚Üí  -scheme AppTests \
   104‚Üí  -only-testing AppTests/MyTestSuite
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí# Run a single test case
   107‚Üíxcodebuild test \
   108‚Üí  -workspace App.xcworkspace \
   109‚Üí  -scheme AppTests \
   110‚Üí  -only-testing AppTests/MyTestSuite/testMyFunction
   111‚Üí```
   112‚Üí
   113‚Üí## Guidelines
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí- Keep `buildableFolders` paths aligned to the target's real file system layout.
   116‚Üí- Avoid overlapping `buildableFolders` with `sources` or `resources` globs in the same target.
   117‚Üí- Open Xcode manually when needed after running `tuist generate --no-open`.
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí## Troubleshooting
   120‚Üí
   121‚Üí**Static side effects warnings:** adjust product types deliberately. Use `Target.product` for local targets and `PackageSettings(productTypes:)` for external products. Making everything dynamic with `.framework` can compile and run, but it may hurt launch time. Prefer static products (static frameworks or libraries) when possible and when they do not introduce side effects.
   122‚Üí
   123‚Üí**Objective-C dependency crashes:** add `-ObjC` or `-force_load` via `OTHER_LDFLAGS` on consuming targets as needed. Reference: `https://docs.tuist.dev/en/guides/features/projects/dependencies#objectivec-dependencies`.
   124‚Üí

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

1‚Üí---
     2‚Üíname: migrating-to-tuist-generated-projects
     3‚Üídescription: Migrates existing Xcode projects to Tuist generated workspaces with build and run validation, external dependency mapping, and migration checklists. Use when adopting Tuist for an existing app or converting a hand-edited Xcode project to generated projects.
     4‚Üí---
     5‚Üí
     6‚Üí# Migrating to Tuist Generated Projects
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí## Quick Start
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí1. Baseline build and run the app with xcodebuild.
    11‚Üí2. Inventory targets, build settings, and external dependencies.
    12‚Üí3. Create `Tuist.swift`, `Project.swift`, and `Tuist/Package.swift`.
    13‚Üí4. Extract settings into `.xcconfig` files and wire them in `Project.swift`.
    14‚Üí5. Generate and build: `tuist generate --no-open` then `xcodebuild build`.
    15‚Üí6. Fix build issues, regenerate, and validate runtime on a simulator.
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí## Preflight Checklist
    18‚Üí
    19‚Üí- Primary app scheme and any extension/test schemes
    20‚Üí- Targets list (app, extensions, tests, helper tools)
    21‚Üí- Deployment targets and bundle identifiers
    22‚Üí- Info.plist locations and entitlements
    23‚Üí- Custom build settings (per target and per configuration)
    24‚Üí- External dependencies (SPM, XCFrameworks, local packages)
    25‚Üí- Build scripts (SwiftGen, Sourcery, codegen)
    26‚Üí- Runtime validation plan (simulator destination and launch command)
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí## Outputs
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí- `Project.swift` and `Tuist.swift`
    31‚Üí- `Tuist/Package.swift` for external dependencies
    32‚Üí- `.xcconfig` files (optional but recommended)
    33‚Üí- Build and runtime validation notes
    34‚Üí- A short migration log of decisions and fixes
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí## Migration Workflow
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí### 1. Baseline the project
    39‚Üí
    40‚ÜíStart by proving the current project builds and runs. Capture the command you use so the generated workspace can be validated the same way.
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí```bash
    43‚Üíxcodebuild build \
    44‚Üí  -project App.xcodeproj \
    45‚Üí  -scheme App \
    46‚Üí  -configuration Debug \
    47‚Üí  -destination "generic/platform=iOS Simulator" \
    48‚Üí  -derivedDataPath DerivedDataBaseline
    49‚Üí```
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí### 2. Map targets and settings
    52‚Üí
    53‚ÜíList every target and its role. Extract build settings into `.xcconfig` files when they are large or shared across targets. Keep deployment targets and bundle identifiers identical to the original project to avoid runtime surprises.
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí### 3. Add Tuist manifests
    56‚Üí
    57‚ÜíCreate the manifests and keep them minimal and close to the existing project.
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí- `Tuist.swift`: enable generation options you need and keep them explicit.
    60‚Üí- `Project.swift`: define targets, sources, resources, scripts, and dependencies.
    61‚Üí- `Tuist/Package.swift`: list external dependencies and map product types.
    62‚Üí
    63‚ÜíUse `.external` for third-party dependencies to keep the graph consistent.
    64‚Üí
    65‚Üí### 4. Handle sources and resources carefully
    66‚Üí
    67‚ÜíBe precise here. Small mistakes often cause large failures later.
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí- `.intentdefinition` files belong in `sources`, not `resources`.
    70‚Üí- `.xcstrings` should remain the primary localization source. Avoid double-including `.strings` or `.stringsdict` from overlapping globs.
    71‚Üí- Use `.folderReference` for bundles like `Settings.bundle`.
    72‚Üí- If a resource bundle is missing, ensure the package target declares `.process("Resources")`.
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí### 5. Generate and build
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí```bash
    77‚Üítuist install
    78‚Üítuist generate --no-open
    79‚Üíxcodebuild build \
    80‚Üí  -workspace App.xcworkspace \
    81‚Üí  -scheme App \
    82‚Üí  -configuration Debug \
    83‚Üí  -destination "generic/platform=iOS Simulator" \
    84‚Üí  -derivedDataPath DerivedDataTuist
    85‚Üí```
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí### 6. Resolve build issues iteratively
    88‚Üí
    89‚ÜíCommon fixes you will likely need:
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí- **Missing SDK frameworks**: add `.sdk(name: ..., type: .framework)`.
    92‚Üí- **SPM resource bundles**: verify `.process("Resources")` and `Bundle.module` usage.
    93‚Üí- **File-system-synchronized groups**: avoid over-excluding directories; compare with the pbx if a type vanishes.
    94‚Üí- **Invalid bundle identifiers**: override with `PackageSettings` or vendor a local package.
    95‚Üí- **Generated sources**: ensure codegen outputs (SwiftGen/Sourcery) are part of the build.
    96‚Üí
    97‚Üí### 7. Validate runtime
    98‚Üí
    99‚ÜíA build is not enough; launch the app on a simulator.
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí```bash
   102‚Üíxcrun simctl boot "iPhone 17 Pro"
   103‚Üíxcrun simctl install booted DerivedDataTuist/Build/Products/Debug-iphonesimulator/App.app
   104‚Üíxcrun simctl launch booted com.example.app
   105‚Üí```
   106‚Üí
   107‚Üí## Common Failure Patterns
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí- **Type not found**: a source file or entire directory was excluded accidentally.
   110‚Üí- **Copy Bundle Resources errors**: Swift files are being treated as resources; fix the resource globs.
   111‚Üí- **Localization conflicts**: `.xcstrings` colliding with `.strings` globs.
   112‚Üí- **Undefined symbols**: missing SDK frameworks or dependency products.
   113‚Üí- **Unrecognized selector at launch**: ObjC categories in static frameworks were stripped. Add `-ObjC` to `OTHER_LDFLAGS` or `-force_load` for the library that defines the category.
   114‚Üí- **Runtime crash on launch**: mismatched bundle id, missing entitlements, or miswired resources.
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí## Migration Notes to Capture
   117‚Üí
   118‚Üí- What changed in `Project.swift` and why
   119‚Üí- Any exclusions or overrides (and the reason)
   120‚Üí- Dependency patches or local vendoring
   121‚Üí- The exact build and run commands used for validation
   122‚Üí
   123‚Üí## Done Checklist
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí- Generated workspace builds cleanly
   126‚Üí- App launches on simulator without immediate crash
   127‚Üí- All targets and extensions build
   128‚Üí- Dependencies are wired through `.external`
   129‚Üí- Settings match the original Xcode project
   130‚Üí

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

content.content:
1‚Üí# AGENTS.md
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThis file provides guidance to AI agents when working with code in this repository. It serves as the root intent node and points to deeper context in subdirectories.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## Repository Map
     6‚Üí- `cli/` - Tuist CLI (Swift) - see `cli/AGENTS.md`
     7‚Üí- `server/` - Tuist Server (Elixir/Phoenix) - see `server/AGENTS.md`
     8‚Üí- `cache/` - Tuist cache service (Elixir/Phoenix) - see `cache/AGENTS.md`
     9‚Üí- `app/` - Tuist iOS and macOS app - see `app/AGENTS.md`
    10‚Üí- `handbook/` - Company handbook (VitePress) - see `handbook/AGENTS.md`
    11‚Üí- `docs/` - Documentation and guides - see `docs/AGENTS.md`
    12‚Üí- `skills/` - Agent Skills (published to [tuist/agent-skills](https://github.com/tuist/agent-skills))
    13‚Üí- `infra/` - Infrastructure and deployment assets - see `infra/AGENTS.md`
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## Global Guardrails
    16‚Üí- Do not modify `CHANGELOG.md` (auto-generated).
    17‚Üí- Do not edit translation `.po` files; only the `tuistit` bot should change them.
    18‚Üí- Do not modify content in languages other than English (source language).
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí## Intent Layer Maintenance
    21‚ÜíWhen making changes in a directory with an `AGENTS.md`, keep that node up to date. If a new subsystem or boundary is introduced, add a new leaf `AGENTS.md` and link it from the nearest parent node.
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí## Git and Pull Requests
    24‚Üí
    25‚ÜíWhen creating commits and pull requests, use these conventional commit scopes:
    26‚Üí- `app` - Changes to the Tuist iOS and macOS app
    27‚Üí- `server` - Changes to the Tuist server (Elixir/Phoenix)
    28‚Üí- `cache` - Changes to the Tuist cache service (Elixir/Phoenix)
    29‚Üí- `cli` - Changes to the Tuist CLI (Swift)
    30‚Üí- `skills` - Changes to the Agent Skills package
    31‚Üí- `docs` - Changes to documentation
    32‚Üí- `handbook` - Changes to the handbook/guides
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí
    35‚ÜíExamples:
    36‚Üí- `feat(server): add new telemetry sanitizer module`
    37‚Üí- `fix(cli): resolve cache artifact upload issue`
    38‚Üí- `feat(cache): add new S3 transfer worker`
    39‚Üí- `feat(skills): add new migration skill`
    40‚Üí- `docs(handbook): update project setup guide`
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí# Tuist CLI (Swift)
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí## Code style
    45‚Üí- Do not add one-line comments unless you think they are really useful.
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí## Workflow
    48‚Üí- The Xcode project is generated with Tuist running `tuist generate --no-open`
    49‚Üí- When compiling Swift changes, use `xcodebuild build -workspace Tuist.xcworkspace -scheme Tuist-Workspace` instead of `swift build`
    50‚Üí- When testing Swift changes, use `xcodebuild test -workspace Tuist.xcworkspace -scheme Tuist-Workspace -only-testing MyTests/SuiteTests` instead of `swift test`.
    51‚Üí- Prefer running test suites or individual test cases, and not the whole test target, for performance
    52‚Üí- When using `swift build`, `swift test`, or `swift package resolve` always include `--replace-scm-with-registry` to avoid switching packages from registry to source control resolution
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí## Testing
    55‚Üí- Use Swift Testing framework with custom traits for tests that need temporary directories
    56‚Üí- For tests requiring temporary directories, use `@Test(.inTemporaryDirectory)` and access the directory via `FileSystem.temporaryTestDirectory`
    57‚Üí- Import `FileSystemTesting` when using the `.inTemporaryDirectory` trait
    58‚Üí- Example pattern:
    59‚Üí  ```swift
    60‚Üí  import FileSystemTesting
    61‚Üí  import Testing
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí  @Test(.inTemporaryDirectory) func test_example() async throws {
    64‚Üí      let temporaryDirectory = try #require(FileSystem.temporaryTestDirectory)
    65‚Üí      // Test implementation
    66‚Üí  }
    67‚Üí  ```
    68‚Üí- Do not modify CHANGELOG.md as it is auto-generated
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí## Linting
    71‚Üí- To check for linting issues: `mise run lint`
    72‚Üí- To automatically fix fixable linting issues: `mise run lint --fix`
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí# Tuist Server (Elixir/Phoenix)
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí## Project Architecture
    77‚Üí
    78‚ÜíTuist Server is an Elixir/Phoenix web application that extends the functionality of the Tuist CLI for iOS/macOS development. It provides binary caching, app preview deployment, build analytics, and Swift package registry services.
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí**Key Technologies:**
    81‚Üí- **Backend**: Elixir 1.18.3 with Phoenix 1.7.12 framework
    82‚Üí- **Databases**: 
    83‚Üí  - PostgreSQL with TimescaleDB extension (primary database)
    84‚Üí  - ClickHouse (analytics database, write-only through IngestRepo)
    85‚Üí- **Frontend**: Phoenix LiveView with JavaScript/TypeScript and esbuild
    86‚Üí- **Package Management**: pnpm for JavaScript dependencies
    87‚Üí
    88‚Üí**Core Architecture Components:**
    89‚Üí- `lib/tuist/` - Core business logic modules (accounts, billing, bundles, projects, registry, etc.)
    90‚Üí- `lib/tuist_web/` - Web interface (controllers, LiveView components, marketing site)
    91‚Üí- `priv/repo/migrations/` - PostgreSQL database schema migrations
    92‚Üí- `priv/ingest_repo/migrations/` - ClickHouse database schema migrations (analytics, write-only)
    93‚Üí- `assets/` - Frontend source files (JS/CSS)
    94‚Üí- `config/` - Application configuration
    95‚Üí
    96‚Üí**Main Business Domains:**
    97‚Üí- **Accounts** - User authentication, organizations, billing management
    98‚Üí- **Projects** - Project management, tokens, permissions
    99‚Üí- **Bundles** - Binary cache management for build optimization
   100‚Üí- **Previews** - iOS app preview generation and deployment
   101‚Üí- **Registry** - Swift package registry implementation
   102‚Üí- **Command Events** - CLI interaction tracking and analytics
   103‚Üí
   104‚Üí## Development Setup
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí**Prerequisites:**
   107‚Üí- PostgreSQL 16 with TimescaleDB extension
   108‚Üí- Mise development environment manager
   109‚Üí- Private key from 1Password for `priv/secrets/dev.key`
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí**Setup Commands:**
   112‚Üí```bash
   113‚Üímise install                    # Install system dependencies
   114‚Üíbrew services start postgresql@16
   115‚Üímise run clickhouse:start      # Start ClickHouse
   116‚Üímise run db:create             # Create database
   117‚Üímise run db:load               # Load database schema
   118‚Üímise run db:seed               # Seed with development data
   119‚Üímise run dev                   # Start development server
   120‚Üí```
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí**Test User Account:**
   123‚Üí- Email: `tuistrocks@tuist.dev`
   124‚Üí- Password: `tuistrocks`
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí## Common Development Commands
   127‚Üí
   128‚Üí**Database Management:**
   129‚Üí- `mise run db:setup` - Complete database setup (create, migrate, seed)
   130‚Üí- `mise run db:reset` - Drop, recreate, and migrate database
   131‚Üí- `mix ecto.migrate` - Run pending migrations
   132‚Üí- `mix ecto.rollback` - Rollback last migration
   133‚Üí
   134‚Üí**Development Server:**
   135‚Üí- `mise run dev` - Start Phoenix development server
   136‚Üí- `mix phx.server` - Alternative way to start server
   137‚Üí- `iex -S mix phx.server` - Start server with interactive shell
   138‚Üí
   139‚Üí**Testing:**
   140‚Üí- `mix test` - Run full test suite (includes database setup)
   141‚Üí- `mix test test/path/to/specific_test.exs` - Run specific test file
   142‚Üí- `mix test test/path/to/test_file.exs:line_number_of_test` - Test single case
   143‚Üí- `mix test --only tag_name` - Run tests with specific tag
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí**Code Quality:**
   146‚Üí- `mix credo` - Run code analysis and linting
   147‚Üí- `mix format` - Format Elixir code
   148‚Üí- `mise run format` - Format all code (Elixir + JS)
   149‚Üí- `mix sobelow` - Security analysis
   150‚Üí- `mise run security` - Run security static checks
   151‚Üí
   152‚Üí**Frontend Assets:**
   153‚Üí- `mix assets.setup` - Install esbuild
   154‚Üí- `mix assets.build` - Build all assets (app, marketing, apidocs)
   155‚Üí- `mix assets.deploy` - Build and minify assets for production
   156‚Üí
   157‚Üí**Database Utilities:**
   158‚Üí- `mix ecto.dump` - Export database structure
   159‚Üí- `mix ecto.load` - Import database structure
   160‚Üí- `mix excellent_migrations.check_safety` - Check migration safety
   161‚Üí
   162‚Üí## Key Configuration Files
   163‚Üí
   164‚Üí- `.mise.toml` - Development environment and tool versions
   165‚Üí- `mix.exs` - Elixir project configuration and dependencies
   166‚Üí- `package.json` - JavaScript dependencies managed by pnpm
   167‚Üí- `config/` directory - Phoenix application configuration
   168‚Üí- `priv/secrets/dev.key` - Development secrets encryption key (not in repo)
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí## Testing Patterns
   171‚Üí
   172‚ÜíThe codebase uses ExUnit for testing. Test files follow the pattern `test/**/module_name_test.exs`. Tests automatically set up a clean database before running.
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí**Running Specific Tests:**
   175‚Üí```bash
   176‚Üímix test test/tuist/accounts_test.exs
   177‚Üímix test test/tuist_web/live/dashboard_live_test.exs
   178‚Üí```
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üí**Testing Guidelines:**
   181‚Üí- **Never modify System environment variables** in tests as they are shared state and can cause flaky tests
   182‚Üí- Use mocks, stubs, or dependency injection to test environment-dependent behavior
   183‚Üí- If environment testing is absolutely necessary, use process-scoped alternatives or test tags to isolate tests
   184‚Üí
   185‚Üí## Code Style Guidelines (Elixir)
   186‚Üí- **Formatting:** Follow standard Elixir and Phoenix conventions. Consider using an Elixir formatter.
   187‚Üí- **Imports/Aliases:** Use `alias` for modules used multiple times. Avoid `import` unless for specific DSLs (e.g., Ecto.Query).
   188‚Üí- **Modules Aliases:** Always declare module aliases at the module level in files, not within individual functions. This improves readability and avoids repetition.
   189‚Üí- **Mocking:** Copy the modules for mocking in @server/test/test_helper.exs not in the individual functions.
   190‚Üí- **Types:** Utilize typespecs (`@spec`) for public functions.
   191‚Üí- **Naming Conventions:**
   192‚Üí    - Modules: PascalCase (e.g., `MyModule`)
   193‚Üí    - Functions: snake_case (e.g., `my_function`)
   194‚Üí    - Variables: snake_case (e.g., `my_variable`)
   195‚Üí- **Error Handling:** Prefer tagged tuples `{:ok, value}` and `{:error, reason}` for functions that can fail. Use exceptions for unrecoverable errors.
   196‚Üí- **Credo:** Adhere to rules in `.credo.exs`.
   197‚Üí    - Timestamps in migrations should be `:timestamptz`.
   198‚Üí    - Timestamps in `lib/` should be `:utc_datetime`.
   199‚Üí- **Comments:** Add comments for complex logic or non-obvious code. Remove `TODO` comments once addressed.
   200‚Üí
   201‚Üí## Translation Management (Gettext)
   202‚Üí
   203‚Üí**Important:** Translations are managed through Weblate. Do not manually edit translation files.
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí**Translation File Types:**
   206‚Üí- `.pot` files (templates) - **CAN be modified** by developers when adding/changing translatable strings
   207‚Üí- `.po` files (translations) - **MUST NOT be modified** by developers
   208‚Üí- Only the `tuistit` bot should modify `.po` files
   209‚Üí
   210‚Üí**Workflow:**
   211‚Üí1. Add translatable strings using `dgettext/2` in your code
   212‚Üí2. Run `mix gettext.extract` to update the `.pot` template files
   213‚Üí3. Commit only the `.pot` files (and your code changes)
   214‚Üí4. Weblate will automatically sync the `.pot` changes and create translation PRs via the `tuistit` bot
   215‚Üí5. **Never run `mix gettext.extract --merge`** in your PRs as this modifies `.po` files
   216‚Üí
   217‚Üí**Key Principles:**
   218‚Üí- Currency symbols and monetary amounts should NOT be wrapped in `dgettext/2` - they must remain consistent across languages
   219‚Üí- Descriptive text around prices (like "and up", "per unit") SHOULD be translatable
   220‚Üí- Example: `"0‚Ç¨ " <> dgettext("marketing", "and up")` ‚úÖ
   221‚Üí- Anti-example: `dgettext("marketing", "0‚Ç¨ and up")` ‚ùå
   222‚Üí
   223‚Üí**CI Protection:**
   224‚ÜíThe CI pipeline will fail if any `.po` files are modified by anyone other than `tuistit`.
   225‚Üí
   226‚Üí## Deployment
   227‚Üí
   228‚ÜíThe application deploys to Render with different environments:
   229‚Üí- `mise run deploy:staging` - Deploy to staging
   230‚Üí- `mise run deploy:canary` - Deploy to canary
   231‚Üí- `mise run deploy:production` - Deploy to production
   232‚Üí
   233‚Üí## Important Notes
   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí- Always run `mix ecto.migrate` after pulling database migrations
   236‚Üí- Use `mise run install` after pulling dependency changes
   237‚Üí- The application requires TimescaleDB extension - install it if migrations fail
   238‚Üí- Local development connects to `http://localhost:8080` for Tuist CLI integration
   239‚Üí
   240‚Üí# Tuist Handbook
   241‚Üí
   242‚Üí## Overview
   243‚Üí
   244‚ÜíThe Tuist handbook is a VitePress-based documentation site that contains company policies, procedures, and guidelines. It's organized into several main sections:
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí- **Company**: Mission, vision, principles, and leadership information
   247‚Üí- **Security**: Comprehensive security policies and procedures
   248‚Üí- **Engineering**: Technical standards, practices, and technologies
   249‚Üí- **People**: Benefits, values, code of conduct, and how we work
   250‚Üí- **Marketing**: Guidelines and case studies
   251‚Üí- **Product**: Product development processes
   252‚Üí- **Support**: Support processes and procedures
   253‚Üí- **Community**: Community-related content
   254‚Üí
   255‚Üí## Technical Details
   256‚Üí
   257‚Üí### Building and Testing
   258‚Üí
   259‚Üí- **Build command**: `mise run handbook:build` (can be run from any directory)
   260‚Üí  - This command also verifies that there are no dead links
   261‚Üí- **Development server**: `mise run handbook:dev` (from the handbook directory)
   262‚Üí- **Deployment**: The handbook is automatically deployed to Cloudflare Pages at handbook.tuist.io
   263‚Üí
   264‚Üí### Directory Structure
   265‚Üí
   266‚Üí```
   267‚Üíhandbook/
   268‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .vitepress/
   269‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ config.mjs    # Navigation and site configuration
   270‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ handbook/         # Content directory
   271‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ company/
   272‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ security/
   273‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ engineering/
   274‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ people/
   275‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ marketing/
   276‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ product/
   277‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ support/
   278‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ community/
   279‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json
   280‚Üí```
   281‚Üí
   282‚Üí## Working with Security Policies
   283‚Üí
   284‚ÜíWhen creating or modifying security policies:
   285‚Üí
   286‚Üí1. **Follow the standard format**:
   287‚Üí   - Include frontmatter with title, titleTemplate, and description
   288‚Üí   - Start with policy owner and effective date
   289‚Üí   - Use consistent section structure
   290‚Üí
   291‚Üí2. **Standard policy sections**:
   292‚Üí   - Purpose
   293‚Üí   - Scope
   294‚Üí   - Policy Statement
   295‚Üí   - Requirements (numbered subsections)
   296‚Üí   - Roles and Responsibilities
   297‚Üí   - Exceptions
   298‚Üí   - Compliance Monitoring
   299‚Üí   - Policy Review
   300‚Üí   - Version History
   301‚Üí
   302‚Üí3. **Key considerations**:
   303‚Üí   - Keep policies practical for a 4-person company
   304‚Üí   - Reference the [shared responsibility model](/security/shared-responsibility-model) when discussing infrastructure
   305‚Üí   - Infrastructure providers (Render, Supabase, Tigris, Cloudflare) handle their own layer security
   306‚Üí   - Focus on application-layer responsibilities
   307‚Üí
   308‚Üí## Navigation Configuration
   309‚Üí
   310‚ÜíThe site navigation is configured in `.vitepress/config.mjs`:
   311‚Üí
   312‚Üí- The sidebar structure should match the directory structure
   313‚Üí- When adding new pages, ensure they're included in the navigation
   314‚Üí- Redirects for moved pages are handled in the buildEnd hook
   315‚Üí
   316‚Üí## Content Guidelines
   317‚Üí
   318‚Üí### Writing Style
   319‚Üí
   320‚Üí- Use clear, concise language
   321‚Üí- Write for a small, technical team
   322‚Üí- Avoid overly bureaucratic language
   323‚Üí- Focus on practical implementation
   324‚Üí
   325‚Üí### Frontmatter Format
   326‚Üí
   327‚Üí```yaml
   328‚Üí---
   329‚Üítitle: Page Title
   330‚ÜítitleTemplate: :title | Section | Tuist Handbook
   331‚Üídescription: Brief description of the page content
   332‚Üí---
   333‚Üí```
   334‚Üí
   335‚Üí### Markdown Conventions
   336‚Üí
   337‚Üí- Use standard GitHub-flavored markdown
   338‚Üí- Include anchors for major sections
   339‚Üí- Use numbered lists for sequential steps
   340‚Üí- Use bullet points for non-sequential items
   341‚Üí
   342‚Üí## Handbook Important Reminders
   343‚Üí
   344‚Üí1. **Always verify builds**: Run `mise run handbook:build` before committing to ensure:
   345‚Üí   - The handbook builds successfully
   346‚Üí   - There are no broken links
   347‚Üí   - Navigation is properly configured
   348‚Üí
   349‚Üí2. **Security policy updates**: When updating security policies, consider:
   350‚Üí   - Impact on the small team size
   351‚Üí   - Alignment with shared responsibility model
   352‚Üí   - Practical implementation requirements
   353‚Üí
   354‚Üí3. **Infrastructure responsibilities**: Remember that Tuist relies on:
   355‚Üí   - Render for application hosting
   356‚Üí   - Supabase for database services
   357‚Üí   - Tigris for data storage
   358‚Üí   - Cloudflare for CDN and edge services
   359‚Üí
   360‚ÜíEach provider handles security at their infrastructure layer, while Tuist focuses on application-layer security.
   361‚Üí
   362‚Üí## Common Handbook Tasks
   363‚Üí
   364‚Üí### Adding a new page
   365‚Üí
   366‚Üí1. Create the markdown file in the appropriate directory
   367‚Üí2. Add proper frontmatter
   368‚Üí3. Update `.vitepress/config.mjs` to include it in navigation
   369‚Üí4. Run `mise run handbook:build` to verify
   370‚Üí5. Commit and create a PR with @tuist/company team as reviewer
   371‚Üí
   372‚Üí### Updating Existing Content
   373‚Üí
   374‚Üí1. Make changes to the markdown file
   375‚Üí2. Verify internal links are still valid
   376‚Üí3. Run `mise run handbook:build` to test
   377‚Üí4. Commit with a descriptive message
   378‚Üí5. Create a PR with @tuist/company team as reviewer
   379‚Üí
   380‚Üí### Moving or Renaming Pages
   381‚Üí
   382‚Üí1. Move/rename the file
   383‚Üí2. Update navigation in `.vitepress/config.mjs`
   384‚Üí3. Add a redirect in the buildEnd hook if needed
   385‚Üí4. Update any internal links to the page
   386‚Üí5. Run `mise run handbook:build` to verify all links
   387‚Üí6. Create a PR with @tuist/company team as reviewer
   388‚Üí
   389‚Üí# Data Export Documentation Maintenance
   390‚Üí
   391‚Üí## Important: Keep server/data-export.md Up to Date
   392‚Üí
   393‚ÜíThe `server/data-export.md` file documents all personal and organizational data that Tuist stores and can export for customers upon legal request. **This file must be kept current whenever database schema changes or new data storage is introduced.**
   394‚Üí
   395‚Üí### When to Update server/data-export.md
   396‚Üí
   397‚ÜíYou **MUST** update `server/data-export.md` when making any of the following changes:
   398‚Üí
   399‚Üí#### Database Schema Changes
   400‚Üí- Adding new tables to PostgreSQL or ClickHouse
   401‚Üí- Adding new columns that store customer/user data
   402‚Üí- Modifying data relationships between tables
   403‚Üí- Adding new Ecto schemas or models
   404‚Üí- Changes to data retention policies
   405‚Üí
   406‚Üí#### File Storage Changes
   407‚Üí- Adding new types of files stored in S3
   408‚Üí- Changing S3 storage path structures
   409‚Üí- Adding new file categories or storage buckets
   410‚Üí- Modifying file upload/download processes
   411‚Üí
   412‚Üí#### New Data Collection
   413‚Üí- Adding new user data fields
   414‚Üí- Implementing new analytics or tracking
   415‚Üí- Adding new integrations that store customer data
   416‚Üí- New features that generate customer-owned content
   417‚Üí
   418‚Üí### How to Update server/data-export.md
   419‚Üí
   420‚ÜíWhen making qualifying changes:
   421‚Üí
   422‚Üí1. **Review the change**: Identify what new data is being stored or how existing data storage is modified
   423‚Üí2. **Update the documentation**: Add or modify the relevant sections in `server/data-export.md`
   424‚Üí3. **Be comprehensive**: Include:
   425‚Üí   - Data type and purpose
   426‚Üí   - Storage location (database table, S3 path structure, etc.)
   427‚Üí   - Data relationships
   428‚Üí   - Retention policies
   429‚Üí   - Export capabilities
   430‚Üí4. **Maintain format**: Follow the existing documentation structure and style
   431‚Üí5. **Test documentation**: Verify that the export process could actually retrieve the documented data
   432‚Üí
   433‚Üí### Legal Compliance
   434‚Üí
   435‚ÜíThis documentation is critical for:
   436‚Üí- GDPR Article 20 (Right to data portability)
   437‚Üí- CCPA data export requirements  
   438‚Üí- General customer data transparency
   439‚Üí- Incident response and data breach notifications
   440‚Üí
   441‚Üí**Failure to keep this documentation current could result in incomplete data exports for legal requests, potentially leading to compliance violations.**
   442‚Üí- Don't modify content in languages other than English (source language)
   443‚Üí

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

24‚Üí  check-releases:
    25‚Üí    name: Check for releasable changes
    26‚Üí    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    27‚Üí    timeout-minutes: 15
    28‚Üí    outputs:
    29‚Üí      cli-should-release: ${{ steps.cli-check.outputs.should-release }}
    30‚Üí      cli-next-version: ${{ steps.cli-check.outputs.next-version }}
    31‚Üí      cli-next-version-number: ${{ steps.cli-check.outputs.next-version-number }}
    32‚Üí      app-should-release: ${{ steps.app-check.outputs.should-release }}
    33‚Üí      app-next-version: ${{ steps.app-check.outputs.next-version }}
    34‚Üí      app-next-version-number: ${{ steps.app-check.outputs.next-version-number }}
    35‚Üí      server-should-release: ${{ steps.server-check.outputs.should-release }}
    36‚Üí      server-next-version: ${{ steps.server-check.outputs.next-version }}
    37‚Üí      server-next-version-number: ${{ steps.server-check.outputs.next-version-number }}
    38‚Üí      cache-should-release: ${{ steps.cache-check.outputs.should-release }}
    39‚Üí      cache-next-version: ${{ steps.cache-check.outputs.next-version }}
    40‚Üí      cache-next-version-number: ${{ steps.cache-check.outputs.next-version-number }}
    41‚Üí      gradle-should-release: ${{ steps.gradle-check.outputs.should-release }}
    42‚Üí      gradle-next-version: ${{ steps.gradle-check.outputs.next-version }}
    43‚Üí      gradle-next-version-number: ${{ steps.gradle-check.outputs.next-version-number }}
    44‚Üí      skills-should-release: ${{ steps.skills-check.outputs.should-release }}
    45‚Üí      skills-next-version: ${{ steps.skills-check.outputs.next-version }}
    46‚Üí      skills-next-version-number: ${{ steps.skills-check.outputs.next-version-number }}
    47‚Üí      should-release-any: ${{ steps.check-any.outputs.should-release }}
    48‚Üí    steps:
    49‚Üí      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    50‚Üí        with:
    51‚Üí          fetch-depth: 0
    52‚Üí      - uses: jdx/mise-action@v2
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí      - name: Check CLI for releasable changes
    55‚Üí        id: cli-check
    56‚Üí        run: |
    57‚Üí          cd cli
    58‚Üí          # Get the latest CLI version tag dynamically
    59‚Üí          LATEST_VERSION=$(git tag -l | grep -E '^[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+$' | sort -V | tail -n1 || echo "0.0.0")
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí          # Check if there are any releasable changes by generating changelog
    62‚Üí          CHANGELOG=$(git cliff --include-path "cli/**/*" --include-path ".xcode-version-releases" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" 2>/dev/null -- ${LATEST_VERSION}..HEAD || echo "")
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí          # Only bump version if there are actual release notes
    65‚Üí          if echo "$CHANGELOG" | sed -n '/<!-- RELEASE NOTES START -->/,/<!-- generated by git-cliff -->/p' | grep -qE '^\*'; then
    66‚Üí            NEXT_VERSION=$(git cliff --include-path "cli/**/*" --include-path ".xcode-version-releases" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" --bumped-version 2>/dev/null -- ${LATEST_VERSION}..HEAD)
    67‚Üí          else
    68‚Üí            NEXT_VERSION="$LATEST_VERSION"
    69‚Üí          fi
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí          echo "Latest CLI version: $LATEST_VERSION"
    72‚Üí          echo "Next CLI version: $NEXT_VERSION"
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí          # Validate that next version is actually newer
    75‚Üí          if [ "$NEXT_VERSION" = "$LATEST_VERSION" ]; then
    76‚Üí            echo "No CLI version change detected (versions are equal)"
    77‚Üí            echo "should-release=false" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    78‚Üí            echo "next-version=$LATEST_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    79‚Üí            echo "next-version-number=$LATEST_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    80‚Üí          elif [ "$(printf '%s\n' "$LATEST_VERSION" "$NEXT_VERSION" | sort -V | head -n1)" = "$NEXT_VERSION" ]; then
    81‚Üí            echo "ERROR: Next version ($NEXT_VERSION) is older than latest version ($LATEST_VERSION)"
    82‚Üí            echo "should-release=false" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    83‚Üí            echo "next-version=$LATEST_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    84‚Üí            echo "next-version-number=$LATEST_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    85‚Üí          else
    86‚Üí            echo "CLI version bump detected: $LATEST_VERSION -> $NEXT_VERSION"
    87‚Üí            echo "should-release=true" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    88‚Üí            echo "next-version=$NEXT_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    89‚Üí            echo "next-version-number=$NEXT_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    90‚Üí          fi
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí      - name: Check App for releasable changes
    93‚Üí        id: app-check
    94‚Üí        run: |
    95‚Üí          cd app
    96‚Üí          # Get the latest app version tag
    97‚Üí          LATEST_VERSION=$(git tag -l | grep -E "^app@[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+$" | sort -V | tail -n1)
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí          # Check if there are any releasable changes by generating changelog
   100‚Üí          if [ -n "$LATEST_VERSION" ]; then
   101‚Üí            CHANGELOG=$(git cliff --include-path "app/**/*" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" 2>/dev/null -- ${LATEST_VERSION}..HEAD || echo "")
   102‚Üí          else
   103‚Üí            CHANGELOG=$(git cliff --include-path "app/**/*" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" 2>/dev/null || echo "")
   104‚Üí          fi
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí          # Only bump version if there are actual release notes
   107‚Üí          if echo "$CHANGELOG" | sed -n '/<!-- RELEASE NOTES START -->/,/<!-- generated by git-cliff -->/p' | grep -qE '^\*'; then
   108‚Üí            if [ -n "$LATEST_VERSION" ]; then
   109‚Üí              NEXT_VERSION=$(git cliff --include-path "app/**/*" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" --bumped-version 2>/dev/null -- ${LATEST_VERSION}..HEAD)
   110‚Üí            else
   111‚Üí              NEXT_VERSION=$(git cliff --include-path "app/**/*" --config cliff.toml --repository "../" --bumped-version 2>/dev/null)
   112‚Üí            fi
   113‚Üí          else
   114‚Üí            if [ -n "$LATEST_VERSION" ]; then
   115‚Üí              NEXT_VERSION="${LATEST_VERSION#app@}"
   116‚Üí            else
   117‚Üí              NEXT_VERSION="0.1.0"
   118‚Üí            fi
   119‚Üí          fi
   120‚Üí
   121‚Üí          # Add app@ prefix if not present and remove any duplicate prefixes
   122‚Üí          if [[ "$NEXT_VERSION" == app@* ]]; then
   123‚Üí            # If it already has app@ prefix, extract just the version number and re-add single prefix
   124‚Üí            VERSION_NUM="${NEXT_VERSION#app@}"
   125‚Üí            # Remove any additional app@ prefixes
   126‚Üí            while [[ "$VERSION_NUM" == app@* ]]; do
   127‚Üí              VERSION_NUM="${VERSION_NUM#app@}"
   128‚Üí            done
   129‚Üí            NEXT_VERSION="app@$VERSION_NUM"
   130‚Üí          else
   131‚Üí            NEXT_VERSION="app@$NEXT_VERSION"
   132‚Üí          fi
   133‚Üí
   134‚Üí          echo "Latest App version: ${LATEST_VERSION:-none}"
   135‚Üí          echo "Next App version: $NEXT_VERSION"
   136‚Üí
   137‚Üí          # Validate and compare versions
   138‚Üí          if [ -z "$LATEST_VERSION" ]; then
   139‚Üí            # No previous version, this is the first release
   140‚Üí            echo "First App release: $NEXT_VERSION"
   141‚Üí            echo "should-release=true" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   142‚Üí            echo "next-version=$NEXT_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   143‚Üí            echo "next-version-number=${NEXT_VERSION#app@}" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   144‚Üí          elif [ "$NEXT_VERSION" = "$LATEST_VERSION" ]; then
   145‚Üí            echo "No App version change detected (versions are equal)"
   146‚Üí            echo "should-release=false" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   147‚Üí            echo "next-version=$LATEST_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   148‚Üí            echo "next-version-number=${LATEST_VERSION#app@}" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   149‚Üí          else
   150‚Üí            echo "App version bump detected: $LATEST_VERSION -> $NEXT_VERSION"
   151‚Üí            echo "should-release=true" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   152‚Üí            echo "next-version=$NEXT_VERSION" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   153‚Üí            echo "next-version-number=${NEXT_VERSION#app@}" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
   154‚Üí          fi
   155‚Üí
   156‚Üí      - name: Check Server for releasable changes
   157‚Üí        id: server-check
   158‚Üí        env:
   159‚Üí          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

   169‚Üí          fi

   172‚Üí          if echo "$CHANGELOG" | sed -n '/<!-- RELEASE NOTES START -->/,/<!-- generated by git-cliff -->/p' | grep -qE '^\*'; then

          if [ "${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.cli-should-release }}" == "true" ] && [ "${{ needs.release-cli.result }}" == "success" ]; then

          if [ "${{ needs.check-releases.outputs.app-should-release }}" == "true" ] && [ "${{ needs.release-app.result }}" == "success" ]; then

## Summary: Skills Directory and Publishing Configuration

Based on my exploration of the repository, here's what I found:

### 1. Skills Directory Structure

The `/Users/pepicrft/src/github.com/tuist/tuist3/skills/` directory contains:

**Root level:**
- `cliff.toml` - Configuration for changelog generation using git-cliff

**Skills content:**
- `skills/generated-projects/SKILL.md` - Agent skill documentation for using Tuist-generated projects
- `skills/migrate/SKILL.md` - Agent skill documentation for migrating to Tuist-generated projects

Each skill file is a markdown document with YAML frontmatter that defines:
- `name`: The skill identifier
- `description`: What the skill is used for
- Content: Detailed guidance on working with Tuist (build commands, workflows, troubleshooting, etc.)

### 2. Publishing Setup - Major Recent Change

**The key recent commit (2df8b776cf) changed skills publishing from NPM to GitHub:**

**Before (deleted):**
- `/skills/package.json` - NPM package configuration for `@tuist/skills`
- Published to NPM registry via OIDC
- Node.js setup in release workflow

**After (current):**
- Skills are now published directly to the `tuist/agent-skills` GitHub repository
- No NPM package needed
- Uses git operations to clone, update, and push to the agent-skills repo

### 3. Release Workflow Configuration

**File:** `.github/workflows/release.yml`

**Release Trigger (`release-skills` job at lines 926-993):**

1. **Check for changes** (lines 335-390):
   - Looks for commits with `skills` scope using conventional commits
   - Uses git-cliff to determine version bumps
   - Supports initial version `0.1.0` if no previous tags exist
   - Tags follow pattern: `skills@X.Y.Z`

2. **Release process** (lines 926-993):
   - Uses `secrets.TUIST_GITHUB_TOKEN` (not OIDC anymore)
   - Removed Node.js setup and `npm publish` steps
   - **New publishing logic** (lines 968-984):
     ```bash
     git clone https://x-access-token:${GITHUB_TOKEN}@github.com/tuist/agent-skills.git /tmp/agent-skills
     rm -rf /tmp/agent-skills/skills
     cp -r skills/skills /tmp/agent-skills/skills
     cd /tmp/agent-skills
     git config user.name "github-actions"
     git config user.email "github-actions@github.com"
     git add -A
     # If there are changes:
     git commit -m "Release ${VERSION}"
     git tag "${VERSION}"
     git push origin main --tags
     ```

3. **Changelog management:**
   - Generates `CHANGELOG.md` in the skills directory using git-cliff
   - Uses `skills/cliff.toml` for changelog configuration
   - Only includes commits with `(skills)` scope

### 4. Changelog Configuration (cliff.toml)

**File:** `/Users/pepicrft/src/github.com/tuist/tuist3/skills/cliff.toml`

Key settings:
- Tag pattern: `skills@[0-9].*` (matches version tags like `skills@0.1.0`)
- Initial version: `0.1.0`
- Filters commits by scope using regex: includes `^feat/fix/docs/perf/refactor/style/test(...\\bskills\\b...)` patterns
- Skips `chore` and `ci` scope commits for skills
- Version bumping strategy controlled by conventional commits (major/minor/patch)

### 5. Documentation Updates

**AGENTS.md (root):**
- Line 12 updated to: `- skills/ - Agent Skills (published to [tuist/agent-skills](https://github.com/tuist/agent-skills))`
- Line 30 updated to: `- skills - Changes to the Agent Skills package` (removed "NPM package" reference)

**Why this change:**
- Original NPM publishing failed due to OIDC (OpenID Connect) issues with npm registry
- GitHub-based publishing is simpler, more direct, and avoids NPM's authentication complexity
- The `tuist/agent-skills` repository now serves as the canonical source for agent skills

### 6. File Paths Summary

- Skills content: `/Users/pepicrft/src/github.com/tuist/tuist3/skills/skills/`
- Changelog config: `/Users/pepicrft/src/github.com/tuist/tuist3/skills/cliff.toml`
- Release workflow: `/Users/pepicrft/src/github.com/tuist/tuist3/.github/workflows/release.yml` (lines 926-993 for skills)
- Documentation: `/Users/pepicrft/src/github.com/tuist/tuist3/AGENTS.md` (lines 12, 30)

The skills package is now managed as a simple directory of markdown files that get pushed to the dedicated `tuist/agent-skills` GitHub repository during releases, making it easier to distribute and consume these agent skills.

**Release Trigger (`release-skills` job at lines 926-993):**

1. **Check for changes** (lines 335-390):
   - Looks for commits with `skills` scope using conventional commits
